From present indications the
1280 seats in the auditorium of the
Maryland Casualty Club House
will be filled by precisely 1280 patrons when the Johns Hopkins Glee
Club files on the stage, and lifts it
collective voice in the harmonious
strains of the University Ode tonight. Then the annual Homewood
Concert of the historic Hopkins
Musical Club will be under way,
and the climax of the greatest season ever experienced by that organization will have finally come.
The concert tonight will be the
eighth of , the present season. The
Club opened in Reisterstown on a
wild December night. The concert
was a success, and it established a
precedent, for all of the other six
have been successes also. Following
their first performance, the Club
came to Baltimore for a concert under the auspices of the Bryn Mawr
League at the Belvedere Hotel.
Then trips to Frederick and Belair
came in rapid succession.

DIFFICULTY IN SEATING ARRANGEMENT
EXPLAINED BY PRESIDENT GOODNOW
In expressing his regret that
many students were unable to gain
admission to the ceremonies celebrating the forty-ninth anniversary
of the Johns Hopkins University,
President Frank Johnson Goodnow explained why the difficulty
developed. The attendance, he said,
was more than was expected inasmuch as a great many notables
from other cities attended the exercises.
Originally, the plans called for
the commencement to be held, as
in former years, at the Lyric Theatre. But, Dr. Goodnow, recalling
that many empty seats were consPicuous in past meetings, deemed
it advisable to shift the scene to the
Peabody auditorium. A crowded

house, the Hopkins executive, intimated, has greater dignity and
makes a better impression than an
overly large hall. He intimated that
the psychological effect was of no
inconsiderable moment, especially
where an affair of nation-wide- interest is under consideration.
When the plans were changed,
Dr. Goodnow informed, the immense out-of-town audience was
not anticipated. The executive expressed regret that Dean Ames who
had urged the students to attend in
force, was placed in an embarrassing position.
In closing, President Goodnow
wished the students to know that
he appreciates the way they received the unfortunate turn of
events.

The description of the plans to
the student body followed on the
heels of similar addresses to the
friends and Alumni of the University. Mr. Hollyday, representing Alexander K. Barton's friends,
formally presented the Cup to the
University at the Commemoration
Exercises last Monday. Two days
previous to that, Emory Niles,
graduate of the Class of 1915, and
Rhodes Scholar, explained the
plan to the Alumni during their
meeting at the Dormitory.
The names already engraved on
the Cup are those of Charles E.
Bowers, Jr., 1921; H. Douglas
Cotton, 1922; John R. Sherwood,
1923; and Randolph Norwood,
1924. Douglas Turnbull, President of the Omicron Delta Kappa
Fraternity, which is sponsoring
the Cup, will make the award on
Class Day this year, and will present the smaller replica cup to the
winner.
Awarded to Senior

"The Alexander K. Barton Cup
is awarded each year to that member of the Senior Class of any
undergraduate department of the
University who has most faithfully served the interests and
ideals of the University, and who,
by his character and influence
throughout his collegiate course,
has best exemplified the qualities
which earned and held for Alexander K. Barton, of the Class of
1914 of the Johns Hopkins University, the respect and affection
of his fellows, both during his
course in college and in his life
outside it. The name of the
selected Senior is engraved annually upon the Alexander K. Barton Cup which is to be mounted
in a conspicuous place in the University and a replica of this Cup
is awarded by Omicron Delta
Kappa to that Senior on Class
Day. The winner of the Cup is
selected by a committee composed
of the Chairman of the Faculty
Committee on Student Affairs,
who serves as Chairman, the Director of Athletics, the Dean of
the College of Arts and Sciences,
and the Dean of the School of
Engineering.

LACROSSE TEAM BEGINS
SCRIMMAGES WITH
SPRING WEATHER
Oxford-Cambridge Cancels Hopkins
Game; Indians May Be Played

There has been a new zest in lacrosse since the breaking up of winter and since the commencement of
warmer and dryer weather. Fall,
or preparatory practice, is ended
and with it has been discontinued
the use of the stone wall. Spring,
or final practice, has begun, two
goals have been set up on the lower
athletic field and a daily scrimmage
is the present rule for practice.
Scheme of Practice

in the daily scrimmage," Coach

This year's campaign will be carried on under the auspices of the
Athletic Board.
An Executive
Committee composed of Magill,
Turnbull, and Parsons will supervise the sale. They have selected
an Organization Committee, composed of twenty men. These men
in turn will choose a team of ten
men, which sub-committees they
will captain.
There will be a big meeting of
the Organization Committee at the
Barn on Saturday, February 28, at
10:30 A. M. At this time each
team captain will receive the names
and addresses of one hundred alumni. The team captain will give to
each member of his committee the
names and addresses of ten of the
Alumni whom the member is to
interview and sell tickets. Previous to their interview each alumnus of the University will have received a letter telling of the campaign. However, the efforts of the
committee will not in any way be
confined to alumni alone.

DIFFICULTY IN SEATING ARRANGEMENT
EXPLAINED BY PRESIDENT GOODNOW
In expressing his regret that
many students were unable to gain
admission to the ceremonies celebrating the forty-ninth anniversary
of the Johns Hopkins University,
President Frank Johnson Goodnow explained why the difficulty
developed. The attendance, he said,
was more than was expected inasmuch as a great many notables
from other cities attended the exercises.
Originally, the plans called for
the commencement to be held, as
in former years, at the Lyric Theatre. But, Dr. Goodnow, recalling
that many empty seats were consPicuous in past meetings, deemed
it advisable to shift the scene to the
Peabody auditorium. A crowded

house, the Hopkins executive, intimated, has greater dignity and
makes a better impression than an
overly large hall. He intimated that
the psychological effect was of no
inconsiderable moment, especially
where an affair of nation-wide- interest is under consideration.
When the plans were changed,
Dr. Goodnow informed, the immense out-of-town audience was
not anticipated. The executive expressed regret that Dean Ames who
had urged the students to attend in
force, was placed in an embarrassing position.
In closing, President Goodnow
wished the students to know that
he appreciates the way they received the unfortunate turn of
events.

The description of the plans to
the student body followed on the
heels of similar addresses to the
friends and Alumni of the University. Mr. Hollyday, representing Alexander K. Barton's friends,
formally presented the Cup to the
University at the Commemoration
Exercises last Monday. Two days
previous to that, Emory Niles,
graduate of the Class of 1915, and
Rhodes Scholar, explained the
plan to the Alumni during their

The names already engraved on
the Cup are those of Charles E.
Bowers, Jr., 1921; H. Douglas
Cotton, 1922; John R. Sherwood,
1923; and Randolph Norwood,
1924. Douglas Turnbull, President of the Omicron Delta Kappa
Fraternity, which is sponsoring
the Cup, will make the award on
Class Day this year, and will present the smaller replica cup to the
winner.
Awarded to Senior

"The Alexander K. Barton Cup
is awarded each year to that member of the Senior Class of any
undergraduate department of the
University who has most faithfully served the interests and
ideals of the University, and who,
by his character and influence
throughout his collegiate course,
has best exemplified the qualities
which earned and held for Alexander K. Barton, of the Class of
1914 of the Johns Hopkins University, the respect and affection
of his fellows, both during his
course in college and in his life
outside it. The name of the
selected Senior is engraved annually upon the Alexander K. Barton Cup which is to be mounted
in a conspicuous place in the University and a replica of this Cup
is awarded by Omicron Delta
Kappa to that Senior on Class
Day. The winner of the Cup is
selected by a committee composed
of the Chairman of the Faculty
Committee on Student Affairs,
who serves as Chairman, the Director of Athletics, the Dean of
the College of Arts and Sciences,
and the Dean of the School of
Engineering.

Confirmed Barnhounds have of
late been roused from their usual
lethargy by the strange sounds issuing from the attic sanctum ot
the Barnstormers, known, by courtesy, as the Studio. Above the
munchings and gurglings of the
hungry mob on the lower floors
rise the energetic knocking of
hammers and the agonizing
screeches of saws. From the
sounds it would seem that the
hard working property staff was
finishing the entire scenery in one
afternoon.
